content:
Diagnosis:	Locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma of left lung
	T4N2M0 (Stage IIIB)
	PD-L1 75%, FGFR3 fusion positive
	Diagnosed March 2024
?
[redacted name] is a 62-year-old gentleman with recently diagnosed locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the left lung. Initial CT chest on 15/3/24 showed a 7.2cm left hilar mass with invasion of the pulmonary artery and extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy. PET-CT on 20/3/24 confirmed high FDG uptake in the primary lesion and mediastinal nodes, with no distant metastases. Endobronchial ultrasound-guided biopsy on 25/3/24 confirmed squamous cell carcinoma with subsequent molecular testing showing FGFR3 fusion and PD-L1 75%.
?
He presents with progressive dyspnoea, now MRCS grade 3, with associated chest pain and weight loss of 6kg over 2 months. His performance status has declined from 1 to 2 over the past month. He has developed a persistent cough productive of blood-streaked sputum.
?
In his background, he has COPD with FEV1 1.2L (45% predicted), hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. He stopped smoking 2 months ago with a 40 pack-year history. He lives alone but has good support from his daughter who attended today.
?
On examination, there is marked reduction in air entry throughout the left lung field with associated dullness to percussion. Oxygen saturations are 92% on room air. There is no clubbing or lymphadenopathy.
?
I have discussed his case with the thoracic surgeons who feel his disease is technically inoperable due to pulmonary artery involvement. Given his PD-L1 status, I recommend combination chemo-immunotherapy with cisplatin/gemcitabine plus pembrolizumab. We will need careful monitoring given his compromised lung function. I have also requested urgent radiotherapy assessment for possible concurrent chemoradiation.
?
The plan is to proceed with baseline cardiac echo, full pulmonary function tests, and CT brain next week. We will review him with all results in the combined lung clinic in 10 days to finalise treatment approach. I have referred him to our lung cancer nurse specialist for additional support.
